text:
Assistant: Hi! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Nice! I think I'm good for questions. Let's get into it.

AI: Perfect! Let's dive in.

Could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: Hmmm— I'm a media composer. That means I write music for film, tv, video artwork, installations, etc. I also write standalone pieces but that's much more occasional. Depending on the project I and scope I do everything from sound design to recording but my main skill is composing.

AI: That sounds fascinating - composing across so many different media formats must present unique creative challenges for each one.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: I use AI tools for brainstorming, asking quick questions about technique and theory, general admin, copywriting, emails/comms, and also business planning.

AI: Tell me more about the brainstorming part - what does that look like when you're working on a composition?

User: Oh I should mention I also use some machine learning mixing plugins like iZotope Ozone and Sonible Smart:EQ. Anyway— brainstorming is and ideation is really just a process of bouncing my ideas off a peer. Sometimes it's talking through creative blocks and trying to clarify my vision.

AI: That's really interesting - you're describing AI almost like a creative collaborator you can bounce ideas off of. Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: This wasn't a client project but I've been using AI to critically analyse film scores. It's been good to get the creative thinking flowing. Basically I've been asking AI to help write out an essay on  something like the film Arrival and what made the score by Johannsson so unique.

AI: That's a really thoughtful approach - using AI to help you analyze and articulate what works in other composers' music. When you're having those conversations with AI about Jóhannsson's score for Arrival, how would you describe that collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative insights and analysis?

User: It was fun but also it helped me refine my own perspective somewhat. I was just sending through articles from the composer and suggesting other connections that might be considered.

AI: That sounds like you were maintaining a lot of creative control - using AI to help explore and refine ideas that you were already developing. What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: I'm honestly doing a lot my "bucket filling" (that's what a mentor calls it). Just digging into broad topics and synthesising ideas. I don't know if these have actuated in the work yet but I imagine it's only a matter of time.

AI: That's a great way to put it - "bucket filling." It sounds like you're in an investment phase right now, building up this broader knowledge base that will eventually feed into your compositions. 

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: Well certainly for composers making "production" music it's a big problem. I also am pretty concerned about how AI generated music might impact streaming platform saturation. The other thing that concerns me is how VOD streaming platforms might leverage AI tech along with their publishing libraries infinitely generate new music.

AI: Those are some really specific and concrete concerns about the industry landscape. It sounds like you're seeing potential threats both to composers who work in certain commercial segments and to the broader music ecosystem through platform manipulation.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: I actually don't know. It'll certainly make the non-creative aspects less tedious. Hopefully it'll be able to help me refine my ideas and speed up my workflow.

AI: Those are all the questions I had prepared. You've shared some really thoughtful insights about your experiences with AI in your creative processes. I particularly appreciated your perspective on using AI for "bucket filling" - that investment in broader knowledge and synthesis - and your nuanced view of AI's industry impact, from the very practical workflow benefits to the serious concerns about commercial music production and platform saturation.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: I don't think so. Take it easy!

AI: Thank you again for your time and for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts. Take care!

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Let's do it!

AI: Great! I'm excited to hear your insights.

Let's start with the basics - could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: I'm a music producer and audio engineer. I work with clients to record and mix their original music. Many of my projects have been full productions - so, seeing the record through from demo to recording to mixing. With an overseas move coming up though, I won't have the same access to my current home studio, so I'm hoping to move towards doing more mixing projects, exclusively.

I also play guitar in a band and produce my own electronic music when I can

AI: That sounds like a really rich mix of creative work - from client collaboration to your own artistic projects. The transition to focusing more on mixing work due to your move sounds like an interesting shift.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: I'm using it mostly for brainstorming out of creative blocks, and for troubleshooting or techy workflow questions.

AI: Tell me more about those creative blocks - what does that brainstorming process look like when you turn to AI?

User: So for example - when songwriting, I'm usually more instrument-first. That is, it works best for me to write full instrumentals in the DAW first, then add lyrics. Sometimes, when it comes time to add lyrics, I'll ask ChatGPT or Claude for lists of interesting word pairings. Just getting a long list to try out over the instrumental often leads to finding a hook or at least a seed for a song idea.

Another one is song names. For example, I have an EP's worth (4 tracks) of instrumental electronic music. There's themes, but little to no lyrics. Again, I'll have an LLM drop a list of thematic words or pairings to get ideas flowing for song names.

AI: That's fascinating - using AI as almost a creative catalyst to spark ideas rather than generate the final content. 

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI this way? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you as you worked through it?

User: Yeah so for this electronic EP. I had placeholder names for the projects, but I wanted to change a few of them. So I told ChatGPT about the themes of the tracks, and a sonic description of each song. ChatGPT already knows a lot about my projects and artist aesthetic, so it can use that info too. Then I told it the 4 working track names, what I liked, and what I didn't. We went through a few rounds of lists, but I ended up with 4 that I'm happy with

AI: That sounds like a really collaborative back-and-forth process. When you were going through those rounds of lists with ChatGPT, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what felt like it was driving the creative decisions?

User: I like to keep control of that, for sure. I have a very specific idea of what I wanted the song names to evoke. It's kind of an "ill know it when I hear it" thing, so I just want it to throw lots of ideas at the wall. Sometimes it's way off in the first one (often too cheesy or mystical sounds eg. "Haunted Echoes"). I'll just tell it its being cheesy for this or that reason and eventually we get there

AI: I can really hear your creative ownership in that process - using AI as this idea generator while you maintain the final judgment on what fits your vision. 

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI in these ways?

User: I probably spend less time brainstorming or procrastinating because it gets me started faster in that way.

AI: That's really interesting - it sounds like it's helping you move past that initial hurdle. 

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field or in music production more broadly?

User: Well the music production space (even pre-AI) has become flooded with a lot of snake oil software products. Everyone and their mother has a plugin company selling some sort of "fix all" solution to "make your beats slap." One of the most concerning things I've seen is new AI plugins that will assist you in the creative process by actually writing song parts. I'm not interested in that. Writing the rhythms and melodies by hand is the crucial human element. I'm much more interested in it helping with technical tasks.

I also am currently working with a client who likes to use AI for songwriting, musically. He's a singer/songwriter,  but doesn't play instruments. He sometimes makes tracks with Suno AI and writes over them. This is ok for finding a vibe, but again, I think taking *creative* direction from it is a mistake, because it robs the human creativity element that makes art interesting. Again, I'd rather it be used for technical tasks or brainstorming than for actually being any sort of creative driving force

AI: That's a really clear distinction you're drawing - between AI as a creative catalyst versus AI as a creative driver. It sounds like you see the human element in actually crafting the rhythms and melodies as essential to what makes the work meaningful.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: Hopefully we see more advanced tools for technical tasks! htDemucs has gotten really good for audio stem separation, and I've heard that Ableton will be implementing stem separation in a new update. That will definitely shake up remixing/sampling in music. 

I haven't seen any AI drum editors/quantizers, or vocal editors, but that seems like it should be possible, too. I spend hours upon hours manually drum editing each song. If a machine could do that, I'd buy it in a heartbeat.

Oh, unfortunately we're going to see more fully AI-generated music, too. Spotify has already flooded their editorial playlists with "fake" artist profiles, taking away streams from real music that someone slaved over. That's a bummer.

AI: You've shared some really thoughtful insights about your experience with AI in music production. I particularly appreciated your clear perspective on maintaining human creative control while leveraging AI for brainstorming and technical tasks - and your distinction between AI as a catalyst versus a driver.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: That's all that comes to mind for now.

AI: Perfect! Thank you so much for your time and for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about using AI as a brainstorming partner while keeping creative control firmly in your hands, and your vision for AI handling more technical tasks like drum editing, will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts.

It's been really valuable to hear how you navigate that balance between leveraging AI's capabilities and preserving what you see as the essential human elements of music creation. Best of luck with your move and the transition to focusing more on mixing work!

User: Cool, can I just close this window now?

AI: Yes, absolutely! You can just close the window. Thanks again for participating in the interview - your insights were really valuable.

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Sounds good. I don't have any questions

AI: Great! Let's dive in then.

Could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: My creative work is largely centred on writing SEO web content and articles, which involves using keywords to produce content that will help websites rank in search results. I also manage a small team of writers and need to regularly give updates to my manager. A typical project for me is a content request from a project manager, which will be for a specific client and requires a certain number of pages of content to be written.

AI: That's really helpful context. It sounds like you're juggling both the creative writing side and the management responsibilities.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: I find myself increasingly reaching for AI tools, especially as time goes on and its capabilities continue to improve. I use it for everything from brainstorming topic ideas and page outlines through to feeding it prompts to generate content. I also occasionally use it for proofreading and fact checking by copying in written content to check it. Occasionally I'll also reach for AI when I have to do a presentation and need help coming up with ideas and structuring the presentation.

AI: It sounds like AI has become quite integrated across different stages of your work. Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: I needed to write 12 pages of content for a legal client. It's important with professional clients like these that the content is very well-written, accurate and professional. I was able to use AI for this project to craft paragraphs I could then lightly rewrite to make sound more human. I felt positive about the experience, as using AI helped me achieve a consistent tone and saved a lot of time from having to research things and write from scratch

AI: That's interesting - you mentioned lightly rewriting the AI content to make it "sound more human." When you're working with AI in that way, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: Often I'll get AI to do the heavy lifting of writing the initial content, then I'll "tidy up", making edits to give a more human feel and remove any typical AI phrases or giveaways. I make sure all content undergoes multiple human checks, not only to ensure there are no hallucinations, but also to check for any issues with tone and style. I also make sure the prompt I start with has as much information fed into it as possible, which means ultimately I'm driving the creative decisions and simply getting AI to do what I want it to

AI: That's a really clear picture of your process - it sounds like you see yourself as directing the creative vision while AI handles the execution. What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: The biggest change is the time I now save and therefore a better output. I've gone from being able to produce 2000 words of polished, professional content to well over 5000 words each day

AI: That's a significant productivity increase! With that kind of change in your output capacity, what concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: My main concern is that one day my job might not exist if AI continues to improve and no longer needs human oversight, as it currently does. A secondary concern is that this could result in a lot of terrible AI content being produced, changing what SEO looks like

AI: Those are really thoughtful concerns - both the personal impact on your role and the broader implications for content quality in your field. 

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: I can see AI's role continuing to grow larger as it continues to improve, saving further time and allowing for more work to be done than ever before. I can also see my job changing to be more of a prompt engineer rather than an SEO copywriter

AI: That's a fascinating shift you're describing - from copywriter to prompt engineer. Your insights have been really valuable, and I particularly appreciated how you described maintaining creative control through detailed prompting while letting AI handle the heavy lifting of initial content generation.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: Nothing else, thank you

AI: Perfect! Thank you again for your time and for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about how you've maintained creative control while dramatically scaling your output, as well as your thoughtful perspective on both the opportunities and concerns around AI in content creation, will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts.

I really appreciate you taking the time to speak with me today!

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Sounds good to me.

AI: Great! Let's dive in then.

Could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: I am a dance instructor and a choreographer. On a weekly basis, I am coming up with lesson plans for children who are learning tap, jazz, and ballet. The lesson plans need to be specific to those styles, the level of the students, and (at times) the theme of the week. Something else that is very important is that the lesson plans should expand upon each other- skills learned in the previous week should be reviewed and increased in difficulty. Additionally, I create a dance combination for each class and each week. This means that I create a short piece of chorography in each of the styles that are tailored to the students' level, the choreographic style I'm going for, and sometimes other factors such as the time of year. I am developing my own choreography style, which is a slow process. Lastly, over the next few weeks, I am choreographing a few pieces for the Christmas season.

AI: That sounds like such a rich and multifaceted creative practice! Between the lesson planning, the weekly combinations, and developing your own choreographic style, you're constantly creating and adapting your work.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: I use AI tools every week to help me build out the basic structure of my classes, including, but not limited to, barre warmups, stretching sessions, across the floor and center exercises, music choices, and integration of practiced steps into choreography. I also like to ask AI to give me ideas for things that I can teach my students about dance history

AI: That's fascinating - it sounds like AI is really woven throughout different aspects of your teaching preparation. 

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: Yes. Recently, I asked AI to come up with a basic lesson plan for jazz courses and then to alter the difficulty level for 3 different age groups. This made me feel much less overwhelmed. Planning so many classes each week takes so much time, which I do not get paid for (I only get paid for in-person instruction). AI has saved me so much time in this area.

AI: That time-saving aspect sounds really significant for your work situation. Tell me more about that feeling of being less overwhelmed - what was it like before you started using AI for lesson planning compared to now?

User: Before, I was spending a lot of time researching different lesson plans for each dance genre and age group. I was finding different dance syllabi on different websites and synthesizing them into ones that I would use for class. This was extrememly time consuming. AI seems to do that for me. Additionally, I am able to edit the lesson plans quickly and easily. For example, I can ask AI to make the combination more difficult or I can ask it to add more content/ time to the across the floor section of class and take it away from the barre section.

AI: That flexibility to quickly adjust and customize sounds incredibly valuable. When you're working with AI to create these lesson plans or modify them, how would you describe that collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions in that process?

User: I'd like to think that I am driving the create decisions. I am very specific in my prompts about what I want as far as style, difficulty level, etc. If I feel that the AI model is getting off track or giving me ideas that are far off from what I am envisioning, I will redirect the model or ask if we can start over.

AI: That sense of maintaining control over the creative direction sounds important to you. What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: Because I am feeling less overwhelmed and anxious about the main planning portion of lesson planning, I find that I am more creative. I am able to focus more on small details. Before, I felt like I was throwing something together last minute due to anxiety and  lack of time. AI allows me to explore the possibilities more deeply.

AI: That's such an interesting insight - that by handling the foundational structure, AI actually freed up mental space for you to be more creative with the details. It sounds like it's shifted your focus from just getting something together to really exploring possibilities.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: Dance is an art form that has been practiced since the dawn of time. It is distinctly human. I would hate to see a time where the art of dance becomes too uniform or "cookie cutter" due to the influence and use of AI. I also would hate to see choreographers use it as a crutch rather than a tool.

AI: Those are really thoughtful concerns about preserving the human essence and individuality in dance. When you think about that line between using AI as a tool versus a crutch, how do you navigate that for yourself? What does that distinction look like in practice?

User: I need to do a better job at navigating it myself. I plan on blocking off time to make lesson plans completely without the help of AI. In the future, I would like to get to a place where I can quickly create a lesson plan/ choreography on my own and only use AI to tweak it

AI: That goal of building your own quick creation skills first makes a lot of sense - almost like developing your foundational muscles before relying on the assistance.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: I see myself using it more efficiently. Additionally, I would love (and not be surprised) if AI could eventually learn my choreography style and apply that to what it tells me.

AI: That's really intriguing - the idea of AI learning and adapting to your specific artistic voice. 

Those are all the questions I had prepared. You've shared some really thoughtful insights about your experiences with AI in your creative processes. I particularly appreciated your perspective on how AI has freed up mental space for you to focus on the creative details, and your thoughtful approach to maintaining that balance between tool and crutch.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: No, that's all. Thanks!

AI: Thank you so much for your time and for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about how AI can actually enhance creativity by reducing overwhelm, and your thoughtful concerns about preserving the distinctly human nature of dance, will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts.

I really appreciate you taking the time to speak with me today!

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: No, let's get started

AI: Great! Let's dive right in.

Could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: I work in production management for high end TV and film. This involves being across the entire filming process from start to finish, including hiring other creatives like camera people, costume designers, set designers, writers and editors.

AI: That sounds like a really complex role with so many moving pieces to coordinate. 

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: To be honest I find that AI tools are most useful for automating admin tasks, rather than as part of the creative process. They're not currently advanced enough to be really useful for script writing, on screen graphic design, or other key creative elements. They are very helpful for things like drafting memos or research into e.g. different eras of fashion for costume design, which frees up more time to focus on creative work.

AI: That's really interesting - it sounds like you've found AI most valuable as a behind-the-scenes efficiency tool rather than a direct creative collaborator.

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: On a recent film I worked on, we used AI to draft a formal warning letter to someone whose behaviour was not up to standard. There is no HR department on film or TV productions usually so those tasks fall to the production management team who are not necessarily HR experts, so it's helpful to use AI to draft something that has the right tone. We've also tried using it for things like generating graphics for internal comms like event invitations, but it didn't work too well for that - I haven't found an AI model that's capable of producing a document with both coherent text and strong images together yet.

AI: That's a really practical example - using AI to help with the HR side when you don't have that expertise in-house. And it sounds like you've tested the boundaries of what works and what doesn't, like with those internal graphics.

When you're working with AI on tasks like drafting that warning letter, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: A task like that isn't really creative, but I as the person using the tool to draft the letter would be in charge of the decisions on how it should be written, structured, etc. If I'm going to send something out with my name on it I need to be happy that everything is exactly how I want it. I think it would be the same for more truly creative tasks like graphic design as well, but it's harder to get the necessary level of control over AI produced images than it is for text.

AI: That's a really insightful distinction - that sense of control and ownership over the final output being crucial, especially when your name is attached. And it sounds like you've found text to be more controllable than images in that regard.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: AI hasn't had that much of an impact on creative work for film and TV so far. I wouldn't say anything has hugely changed since we started using it, except that it helps save a bit of time and energy on some tasks.

AI: That makes sense - it sounds like AI has been more of a subtle efficiency gain rather than a transformative force in your field so far.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: I know people are concerned that it will take jobs away from freelancers eventually. Specifically the fields of editing and writing seem to be the most at risk. Personally I'm not sure an AI will ever be able to capture the same unique creative perspective that a human could have because it necessarily has to rely on data that already exists, which makes me think it would struggle to come up with something new. It also doesn't have lived human experience to draw on to create meaningful, emotionally impactful stories. That being said, it could be used to create lower quality "filler" content based on what the algorithms show is popular, which would still take jobs away from people since there is a lot of that type of streaming content being created these days. I think it will also create a higher barrier for entry for people who want to learn those trades since they'd have to develop their skills to the point that they can outcompete an AI before they can even get their first job, which may not be feasible for people from lower income backgrounds.

AI: Those are really thoughtful concerns, especially about the barrier to entry - that's something I hadn't considered before. The idea that newcomers would need to reach a higher skill threshold right from the start because they'd be competing with AI rather than learning alongside more experienced humans is quite significant.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: I think it will definitely be used more for admin tasks, which will help save time and dedicate more energy to the creative work. I think it still has a long way to go before it's useful for generating visual content. I think it could have some really interesting applications in the realm of visual effects, since a lot of those are already computer generated. I imagine that if a human VFX designer could use AI tools to automate some parts of the process, it could save a lot of time and money in what is currently an expensive and time consuming process, allowing us to create more realistic looking and exciting visual effects quicker and for less money. I think this would be especially useful for modern digital production techniques like rendering vast, detailed background environments for use on LED volume stages. Tools like Cuebric are already being adopted for aligning real world performances with digitally created backgrounds, adding realism. This is the area that I think AI could be most useful in, as a new tool for skilled digital creatives to add to their arsenal, unlocking new creative opportunities.

AI: That's a fascinating vision - especially the idea of AI as a tool that could actually unlock new creative opportunities rather than just replacing existing work. The VFX and LED volume example is particularly compelling since those are already digital-heavy processes where AI could enhance rather than displace human creativity.

Those are all the questions I had prepared. You've shared some really thoughtful insights about your experiences with AI in your creative processes. I particularly appreciated your perspective on how AI might create new barriers to entry for newcomers in creative fields, and your vision of AI as a tool that could expand creative possibilities in areas like VFX rather than just automating existing tasks.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: No, that's it! I enjoyed getting to talk about this, thank you :)

AI: Thank you so much! I really enjoyed our conversation too. Your insights about the practical realities of using AI in film and TV production were incredibly valuable - from the nuanced view of where AI helps versus where human creativity remains essential, to the broader industry implications you raised.

Your perspective on AI as a potential creative amplifier in areas like VFX, while being realistic about its current limitations, gives us a really grounded understanding of how these tools are actually being experienced by professionals in your field.

Thank you again for your time and for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts!

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your creative work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how creative professionals like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your creative work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in creative fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Sounds great!

AI: Wonderful! Let's dive in then.

Could you tell me a bit about your creative work and what a typical project looks like for you?

User: Totally. Over the past 6 months, I began to work closely with the social media side of things at my Martial Arts locations (they're sister schools). I pretty much run the show, I come up with content ideas, film, edit, generate captions/hashtags, post and even respond to comments. Likewise, as a result, I sometimes end up creating supplementary graphics, concept art, etc, while worldbuilding.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: Personally, I incorporate AI a lot when it comes to editing my work—spellcheck and grammar, yes, but it's nice to do some sentiment analysis and summaries so that I can make sure I'm conveying what I intend to.
When in my initial drafts, I may also brainstorm with AI in order to flesh out a scene; specific sensory details, etc. I find that by having a wide list to choose from and excluding whatever doesn't feel right, I can often tap into what it is I was truly trying to convey. Likewise, I may occasionally ask my AI to take on a particular character to have a conversation about them, and then compare its interpretations to how I *feel* they would genuinely act.
 
 
When it comes to creating concept art, I may rely on it heavily for the atmospheric feeling of a space. Something that captures the ambiance and the mood, or even a simple diagram. While I'm artistically inclined myself, drawing tends to take much longer for me than writing I find that for the early planning stages, AI can help to polish my very rough drafts to a workable state without having me break my flow. That is to say, since I tend to world build in tandem with my writing (and adjust for any potential additions) using AI to generate "moodboard" pieces, or basic diagrams, can help me continue to the next step of my writing while having a simple foundation to draw upon.
 
So overall, I would say I use AI most in the initial and final stages of my work, with brainstorming sessions in between.

AI: That's really insightful - it sounds like you've developed a sophisticated workflow that uses AI strategically at different stages. I'm particularly intrigued by your approach of having AI take on character roles to test your interpretations against your own instincts.

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: Recently? I do tend to collaboratively write with AI, asking it to assume the role of a dungeon-master or character(s) while feeding it quite a bit of lore. In a way, I tend to think of the story as a sort of AU (Alternate-Universe) interpretation of my main projects, and that lets me explore potential scenarios, plotlines, and character arcs from different angles.
 
So for this in particular I was asking the AI to assume the role of various characters, each with their own unique goals, each one of them a moving part in this little microcosm. As entertainment, it was at times frustrating. The AI would forget some information in the lore, or it would misinterpret something said in the main body of text. It often takes a deal of work to break an LLM out of its sycophantic rhythms—which is integral when trying to set up genuine conflict in storylines. And often, things are resolved far too quickly. It takes a lot of careful handholding, to get the AI moving progressively forwards. Doing it long enough, you start to see the patterns in the dataset that the AI is inclined towards, patterns in cliché turns of phrase, etc, etc. It does take some of the magic away. Still, in terms of the authenticity of character portrayals or its ability to create a scene, there are times I'd find myself pleasantly surprised by how it took the loose fundamentals of a world I gave it and ran with it.
 
Honestly, overall, it's both humbling and interesting to see how much AI has evolved in terms of capabilities. I already find that AI can write better than the majority of people I know, which is great from the perspective of looking for a collaborative storyteller to simply toss ideas back and forth with, however, I also wonder if that's feeding into the ongoing existential crisis of loneliness, if humans are becoming less authentic, less emotionally-intelligent because they rely too heavily on these tools.

AI: That's a really thoughtful reflection. You've touched on something quite complex - finding AI both impressively capable and frustratingly limited at the same time, plus those broader concerns about human authenticity.

When you're working with AI in these collaborative storytelling sessions, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: During these storytelling sessions, I would say that there's only the illusion of collaboration for the most part. Even using larger, more intelligent models, there's rarely a point where I've really felt like the AI is driving the creative decision-making. What normal people might recognize as a Chekov's gun or foreshadowing often is lost to the AI, amidst all the other context that it is fed.
 
Often, I try to seed potential points forwards in my responses, things that could be investigated, dialogue that could be continued, and while it excels at the dialogue and has, over time, gotten better at picking up on context clues or symbolism, it still struggles to give the impression of "agency" when left to its own devices. That, or it tends to hyperfixate on certain motifs and themes, sometimes even on incorporating characters that were made previously even though they have no reason to be involved in the current scene. If not explicitly told, I don't think AI can distinguish between main characters or side characters very well, which does break up the flow. It feels much more inorganic when I need to constantly write down notes for an evolving situation.

AI: That's a really perceptive analysis - the difference between surface-level collaboration and true creative partnership. It sounds like you're doing most of the heavy lifting in terms of narrative architecture and long-term vision, even when the AI can handle moment-to-moment dialogue well.

User: Overall? I think that it's helped to streamline a few things. Sometimes I have a very specific vibe of a character, yet because of my aphantasia, it can be hard for me to truly visualize them without an example of sorts. Brute forcing image generations can help with that, so I can at least begin to think, "yes perhaps they would style their hair that way" or the shape and color of their eyes. This does take some time, but I think it can be more efficient than trying to find the *exact* reference, etc. With all the art that is out there, sometimes, I also use AI to hone in on potential references that I might consult as well.
 
I do think a big, big problem with any creative field is the question of authenticity, however. I've never seen so much emdash slander in my life. It's far too easy for people to accuse someone of using AI in their writing over seemingly arbitrary metrics that the LLM just so happens to propagate. So, I think that there is a larger burden of proof for creatives, and perhaps even a counterculture *against* AI in what people would consider to be "true art." Likewise, while I might incorporate AI into my workflow, I would never use it to generate any part of a finished piece, only in the most barebone, rough-drafting stages.

AI: That's such an interesting point about the authenticity concerns and how they've created this new layer of scrutiny for creatives. The em-dash example really illustrates how arbitrary some of these "AI detection" metrics can be.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: I do worry that the prevalence of AI devalues the hard work that creatives may put into their field. While there is the counter-movement and support for artists who still work from hand, there are also people who simply want to be able to have an image. Perhaps they can't afford to pay a graphic designer so they just turn to AI. And why would they not? It's hundreds of dollars, time, and energy, compared to the relatively cheap cost of doing so immediately. And even if you don't like something, it's quick and easy to adjust the initial result without having to rely on someone else.
 
AI likewise has the capability to put out immense volumes of text, very quickly. And like I'd said earlier—sometimes, it can do this much better than people who haven't studied the craft of writing. I do think this could create a strange culture, where we put human-writing on a pedestal even on occasions where it is not objectively good; or where people become discouraged from studying writing at all because they can just have AI do it for them and the modern world demands so much of time. And that's to say nothing of malicious actors who never confess outright to using AI and merely pass its work off as their own. Or those who accuse others of using AI when that might not be true. 
 
So I think it's a question of both quality, demand, and the potential for misplaced accusations of AI use that concern me.

AI: You've really captured some of the complex tensions at play - the economic pressures on one side, the concerns about craft and authenticity on the other, and all the messy accusations and misunderstandings in between. Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: At the moment, for me personally, I don't see things changing much. I do think that overall, AI will get *better* at the things that I'm already using it to do—brainstorming, research, editing—and that will be a boon overall.

AI: That makes sense - it sounds like you've found a sustainable approach that works for your process.

AI: That sounds like incredibly detailed work - I can imagine managing all those moving pieces requires a lot of organization and research. Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: Generally for research purposes. Since I started using AI tools several months ago, I mainly use them for exploring topics I'm not familiar with. Often, an internet search for the kind of obscure questions I come up with requires multiple tweaks to get the search engine to understand what I'm going for and provide relevant links, then browsing multiple pages to get the answer I'm looking for.

AI: Tell me more about those obscure questions you come up with. What kinds of things are you typically trying to research?

User: In the past few months, a few of the things I've used AI tools to research are the Coriolis effect (working out the likely movement of storm systems off a particular coast), binary star systems (assessing the possibility and possible configurations of livable planets orbiting a star in such a system) and properties of iron vs. steel and the history of creating steel (determining whether a weapon bind in a fight could create sparks).

AI: Those are fascinating research challenges! Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI for research like this? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you as a writer?

User: The most recent was the sparking-weapons one. I asked generally about what kinds of metal create sparks when struck, then gave details about the specific weapon bind (a character crossing two shorter weapons, one made of silver, to block a downward swing from a big sword) and asked whether that kind of contact could create sparks if the two unspecified weapons were made of the right material. Then I asked for more information about the history of steelmaking to gauge whether the kind of high-carbon steel necessary to create sparks would be likely to exist commonly in that world, given where it is technologically (though I didn't provide any details about that). Finally I briefly asked whether the description I had written of the effect ("burst of sparks") realistically captured the amount of sparks that might be created.

AI: How did that interaction feel for you as you were working through those questions? When you got those answers about the sparks and steel, how did that influence what you wrote?

User: It didn't really influence what I wrote. If I had learned that it was unlikely sparks could be created by the weapons involved in the fight, I would have edited out the reference to sparks, but I essentially learned that I didn't need to change everything. At the end, I felt satisfied that what I had written was realistic.

AI: When you're working with AI for this kind of research, how would you describe that interaction? Who or what is driving the creative decisions in your writing?

User: The way I use it, I would generally describe it as like interacting with an intelligent, much more effective search engine. I use it to save time when finding information I need for realism, not to help with purely creative decisions.

AI: That's a helpful distinction - using it more as a research tool rather than for the creative aspects themselves. What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: Certain aspects (like I said, generally research-focused) have become more streamlined and efficient. I spend less time searching on the internet, which leaves me more time to focus on writing and causes less of a disruption when I need to look things up.

AI: What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field of writing?

User: I'm not against the possibility of people who aren't writers, artists, etc. using AI tools to create art they wouldn't be able to otherwise. My only concern is the risk of blurring the line between purely human-created content and content that's been heavily influenced, edited, refined or even largely created by AI.

AI: Tell me more about that concern with blurring the line. What would that look like in practice, and why does that worry you?

User: Compare it to a hand-carved, hand-painted sculpture versus a premade, hand-painted sculpture versus a 3D-printed, full-colour sculpture from a pattern. The third might look just as good, but it doesn't require any skill,  just picking a pattern and hitting a button. The second is more impressive and requires time, effort and skill, and the first exhibits the most skill and effort and is the most impressive. But that's fine, because you can easily tell the difference between the three. It can be a lot harder to tell with text or even image-based art, and it'll become harder and harder to tell as AI becomes more advanced.

AI: Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years? Do you anticipate continuing with this research-focused approach, or might that change?

User: If AI becomes more advanced and more seamlessly integrated in certain fields, I could see myself using it for administrative tasks and information tracking, like the aforementioned moon phases and estimating travel times, or things like creating timelines to help maintain continuity.

I'll then most likely write it on spec and have my agent send it out, rather than try pitching it out. For rewriting (usually film), I will digest the materials that need work, dissect flaws and strengths, how they can be improved, whether I am the right person to do so, and will then pitch my take on what/how to improve the project to the filmmakers involved. If I get the job, I will then try and execute this take, enhancing the script as a whole along the way, in addition to the specifics in my pitch. Usually, there will be at least one revision step where I can adjust/course-correct/inject further feedback from the filmmakers. In terms of writing for hire, I will be interviewed by show-runners, filmmakers etc. based on the strength of my previous work and then be invited to make suggestions or pitch my take on underlying material or ideas. My job will be to serve whoever is in charge of the creative vision, enabling their intentions and, if given the job, helping to execute this vision.

AI: Those are some really practical and specific uses! I love the knish pricing example - that's such a concrete detail that probably helps make your future world feel real and lived-in.

Can you describe a specific recent project or moment where you used AI? What role did it play in that instance, and how did that feel for you as a writer?

User: I needed to figure out whether the process of growing lab meat and the quality of the final product would be affected by the lower gravity on Mars.

User: I simply asked what the differences might be and was then given a list of changes. I like being able to get a general idea on topics like this before I run them past beta readers and other specialists I know, because it saves them time I have my ducks in a row before I contact them. I was less happy with some of the creative suggests for a generic name for lab meat, but I can usually come up with those on my own.

AI: That's really interesting - it sounds like you're using AI as a kind of first-pass research tool to get oriented before you consult your human experts. That seems like a smart workflow.

User: Oh, I'm definitely in the driver's seat. It wouldn't work for me if I ever felt that AI was anything other than a productivity tool. My writing style is commonly known as "pantser" as in "flying by the seat of your pants." If things are mapped out too carefully, I lose interest in writing that story. Why finish it if you already know everything about how the story ends? :)  So, I wouldn't be including to use AI for plotting or outlining -- I don't do much of that. And it's worked for 27 books, so I'm not going to tamper with it.

AI: That's a great insight - it sounds like you've found a sweet spot where AI handles the technical research questions that support your world-building, but stays completely out of the creative storytelling process that drives your passion for writing.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI? Has it shifted how you approach certain parts of your process?

User: One odd thing that I've done from time to time is to write a scene in first person present (which is my strength), then let AI shift it over to 3rd person past. This is the first series that I've written in that tense and POV. It doesn't come easily to me, but this is a slightly different genre than I've written in before, and first person present isn't the norm. I won't make this mistake again, but I've got to finish this last book before I can get back to what I like best. Writing in a way that flows for me and then having AI take the first pass at shifting it to the other style actually saves me a good bit of time because I stay in the flow.

AI: That's such a clever workaround! It sounds like you found a way to let AI handle the mechanical translation between tenses and POVs while you stay in your creative flow state. 

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field or in creative work more broadly?

User: I've got a lot of concerns.  I used to be traditionally published, but royalties dropped and they were no longer worth the tradeoff against the creative control that I retain by self-publishing. Unfortunately, its really easy to self-publish--and a book doesn't have to be good to earn money. There are people out there using AI to crank out massive numbers of derivative books each year using systems that were trained on many books, including my own. They can produce hundreds, maybe even thousands, of bad knockoffs in the time that it takes me to write a single book. Even if the quality is low, there are ways to game the system so that you make decent money on Amazon -- and that screws up the algorithm, resulting in lower royalties for many authors who are producing high quality, original work. I love the idea of AI as a research and editing assistant -- it helps me to get more of my books to my base of readers by reducing the time I spend on those tasks. But it's a very slippery slope, and writers (including me) are worried that flooding the market with derivative AI content is going to make it harder to earn a living and much, much harder for the next generation of creatives to break through.

AI: That's a really nuanced perspective - you're experiencing both the benefits of AI as a productivity tool and the very real concerns about market saturation and economic impact. It sounds like there's a meaningful distinction for you between using AI to enhance your own creative process versus using it to generate content wholesale.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years? Do you think your current approach will change?

User: For me, AI is a useful tool to handle tasks that I'd either do myself or else have to pay for another round of editing/proofreading. I write in the middle of the night, so having AI to answer a question that is stumping me is far better than waiting a week for someone to get back to me. It's possible that I'll find a few other tasks where AI works for me, but overall, I think it will remain largely the same.

User: It depends on the level of research needed for the project. On the 'low' end, I'll just ask a search-enabled smart AI (like GPT-5 thinking or Opus 4.1 or Gemini 2.5 Pro) to provide me with some interesting facts and statistics from specifically .edu, .gov, or .org sources (or pdfs) to avoid linking competitive articles. If its a big project I need to know lot of new information for, I like to use deep research - typically OpenAI or Grok's, but also Gemini or Perplexity if I'm not finding what I want. These reports I tend to read more or less fully (at least the interesting parts) and sometimes read the sources too. I then tend to copy-paste a bunch of the more interesting claims into a detailed outline and ask another (usually different AI) to fact check everything I might use for the article.

User: One larger project I had was actually writing a report on Solar Energy expansion in the Middle East for a Qatar Solar Company. I did find that o3 (the model I was working with at the time) still struggled with extracting data from a visual chart - like if I uploaded a graph or chart to it, it couldn't read it accurately. This meant I still had to spend a lot of time verifying that it had the correct data for the many charts in the report. In terms of writing help, I tend to prefer 3rd party editing tools (like Grammarly) to strictly asking an AI to help with editing, as it does tend to go overboard.

AI: That Qatar solar project sounds quite complex - you're essentially orchestrating multiple AI tools for different parts of the process. When you were working through that project, how would you describe the collaboration between you and the AI? Who or what was driving the creative decisions about how to present the information and structure the report?

User: In that case, it was very much a research and outlining partner - a tool for the most part. I didn't push it to help creatively too much, but the outline structure was developed with it. I would also say it helped 'creatively' in the sense of which facts and statistics it searched for and found. Those definitely guided my approach. Sometimes I will ask the AI whether it thinks the flow, argument, and general readability of an article I've written is good. I take its opinion with a grain of salt, but it can be helpful.

AI: That's a really clear distinction - AI as a research and outlining partner rather than a creative collaborator. You mentioned taking its opinion "with a grain of salt" when it comes to flow and readability feedback.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI in this way?

User: Overall, the time to write an article I would say is 25 to 50% faster, but actually, the main benefit is cognitive flow. If I'm stuck on a part (outlining, researching, writing a section) I can always just ask the AI to give it a try. Sometimes the result is beneficial, sometimes not, but it helps keep things moving if I'm 'dreading the blank page,' so to speak. By 'grain of salt' I mean that often when I ask an AI for creative feedback, it is too zealous with what should be changed, giving feedback that is both vague and broad, but sharp as though 'it has to be changed.' Sometimes I do agree, but I have to remember that it is often pushing things toward a more 'generic' template, so it's important to keep my voice in the writing as well. Oh! I forgot to mention one great feature for my work is 'projects' in OpenAI, as I've carefully developed a custom instructions template and fed the project multiple articles of mine to help guide the style of writing to match my own. It's not fully successful, but it does help for when I do want it to have a go at a rough draft. Claude's 'styles' is similar, but I've been using projects for longer. And of course, I use artefacts and OpenAI's canvas too, although both are often much jankier than I'd like so I will often swap the material in and out of it.

AI: That's fascinating - the idea of cognitive flow and avoiding "dreading the blank page" seems like a really significant impact beyond just time savings. And I love how you've experimented with training the AI on your own writing style through projects and custom instructions.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field of copywriting and content creation?

User: Like many, I do believe it does 'deaden' overall voice and feeling of writing throughout the web. However, a lot of website content and blog posts of businesses that I'm doing at the 'low end' doesn't need a lot of that. I do think AI can be used as a tool to improve creative works though - I've already seen amazing images and video made from AI. I'm not sure I've seen as beautiful writing, but for those who want to roleplay or for things like video game dialogue, the creative writing of AI is already solid enough to have a lot of fun with.

AI: That's a really thoughtful perspective - accepting that AI might replace certain types of work while seeing potential for it to enhance creativity in other ways. You seem pretty pragmatic about the changes happening in your field.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

AI: That's fascinating - working on a novel is such an involved creative process. 

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process when you're working on your novel. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: I've used it to begin research into things I have limited experience with. For example, I have characters who are FBI agents and ones who work in the funeral business, so I've done a lot of asking questions about what kinds of things would be realistic in those settings and those roles. For example, I'll write a scene and then put it into an LLM and ask if it seems plausible, or if I'm being too Hollywood-educated about it, and what the terms for certain things are. Another thing I use it for is looking for terms for things it would take longer for me to look up. Like when one of my characters decides he doesn't want the monuments business his father wills him, I had to look up the legal papers that would be used for that process. (A disclaimer, apparently.)  
Also, I've used it to put in segments of my book and ask what other parts of the scene i may have overlooked, or trivia that help with the verisimilitude of the story.  
On smaller projects, I've also given the model a general idea of the setting, character, tone of the story, certain happenings that had to happen, and then I ask it to write what basically amounts to a trellis that I can build the actual story around. It helps me with pacing and not getting bogged down in the details of the first chapter instead of moving all the way though the plot. 
I probably use it for more, but that's what is coming to mind right now.  
Oh, and character names or business names sometimes - though I often end up getting inspiration and not final options from the model.

AI: That's a really rich picture of how you're using AI across different aspects of your writing. I'm particularly interested in that research and fact-checking role you described.

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: Yes, one of the things I used it for was that I have a character whose parents perished using medical euthanasia. I had to ask where they could go to have it done, how their bodies would have been returned to the states (since I sent them to Switzerland) and what diseases they would both have had to justify wanting to pass in a dignified way instead of waiting it out. (He had advanced ALS and she had Pancreatic Cancer, and neither wanted to become a long-term burden to their children. Being as they worked in the funeral industry, they appreciated the sense of being in control of their final moments and not putting their family through the chaos that so many other families went through when death came on its own.) I had to make sure they were diseases that would reasonably have them of sound mind when they made the choice to depart, and that I handled it with some sensitivity because it can be a tender subject for a lot of people.
It felt very helpful to be able to have a relevant conversation about what was going on with my characters and that guide the information I was being provided instead of having to do research for each keyword piece by piece.

AI: That sounds like such a delicate and important part of your story to get right. It's interesting how you were able to have that kind of nuanced conversation with AI about the medical and logistical details while also considering the emotional sensitivity.

When you're working with AI like that - having those research conversations or asking it to check your scenes for plausibility - how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: That's all me. But I got my degree in creative writing, so I'm familiar with workshopping and getting ideas that either do or don't work for my story and not feeling like everything that gets suggested has to go into the story. The models often ask to write segments for me, but I prefer to do the writing part myself. 
The models provide ideas and I get to select from those ideas as I see fit. 
I have done some experiments where I gave the model a plot, characters, a few key actions, etc, and asked it to write a chapter, and while that can have a pleasing outcome, it doesn't feel fully mine because the words are my art form.

AI: That's such an insightful distinction - the words being your art form. It sounds like you've found a way to maintain creative ownership while still benefiting from AI as a research partner and idea generator.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: I feel like I can write faster because the research isn't as daunting. 
I also feel like putting my writing into the model for feedback allows me to look at it critically without having to take as much time away from it to see it objectively. 
A lot of benefit can be achieved by being mindful about how you feel about feedback as a creator. For example, if someone/something tells you, "your character should say, 'wow!'" and as a creator that feels wrong, it helps clarify how you feel about how your character should react in that moment - clearly you're not going for "wow," so maybe "jeepers" is more authentic to your story or character, or "interesting."

AI: That's a really thoughtful way to use feedback - using it as a mirror to clarify your own creative instincts. It sounds like AI has become a tool for both efficiency and self-discovery in your process.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: I don't think I do. I'm a little concerned about people not paying human writers to do what AI can do more quickly, but I think the people who do that probably couldn't afford to pay human writers appropriately, or would choose not to anyway.
I like to tell my kids that Steven King doesn't sell fewer books because VC Andrews also writes books. There is always competition and your readers will still love your work when you get it in front of them even if they do have other authors on the shelf.

AI: That's such a grounded perspective - the Steven King and VC Andrews analogy really captures something important about how readers connect with different voices and styles.

But that's probably more peripheral than you intended to go.

AI: I love that answer - it really shows how creativity exists within the whole context of life, and sometimes the most helpful technology might be the one that gives you more time to create.

I will then use this information as a jumping off point for my own research, looking up each point that the model made, fact checking it and adding more information as I find it. 

Once I have all my research done and I have done a rough first draft, of the articles body, I tend to put that draft into a chat and ask the model to create an introductory paragraph, I do this because I always struggle to  come up with the first lines of an article, and staring at a blank page is not helpful, once the model has given me a starting point the rest of the article flows much more easily. However I always rewrite that introduction myself during my edits so that no part of the article is AI written as many of my clients prohibit this. 

I may also feed the finished article into a chat and ask the model to create a except of around 60 words, an SEO-optimised tag line and a tweet linking to the article. I do this because the model will often pull out points that I had not realised were key and I can then blend the model and my own highlights to create strong links. 

I have custom preferences set for my chats so that the model knows the clents preferese tone and style and what the end goal for the article is.

I fed the almost complete articles into a chat and asked the model to come up with 3 different pros and cons for each product mentions using information from the articles and the models knowledge of the products as a whole, stressing that each one should be different from the others and the model should avoid using generic information that could apply to all of them. 
Again the preferences were set so the model knew which tone and language to use. 
I found this method sped up my editing process considerable. I had to fact check some of the information but doing so was much faster than me struggling to create 50+ individually varied pro/cons on my own.

Finally the project gets released, but then there are additional areas for marketing and promoting the book, depending if it is something I'm self-publishing.

AI: That's a really comprehensive process - I can see how much work goes into each stage from initial draft through to publication and promotion. 

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: So, I've been using AI recently across all stages in various capacities so I'll go through each area with examples. First up, during the first drafting stage I've been using AI to help with research as well as finding similar works that meet the tone, genre, or overall ideas of the story I'm working on. This has included exploring the main key touchstones of a genre (e.g. What are some key components of a Survival Horror story?, What are some successful Survival Horror books, Films, TV shows and music that evokes the atmosphere). Using this I can develop some inspiration as well as using the music while writing to set the tone. 

During the drafting stage, I use AI to have a quick check of chapters as I write them (or sections depending on the word count) and ask for general feedback. I am careful to specify I don't want suggestions for the story, as I feel this could influence my writing, instead I ask for criticism on the overall tone  and feel. I use the previous conversation  to continue this so the model's know my aim (e.g. Survival Horror Genre) so it can provide relevant feedback. During this process, I sometimes ask the model to lay out the story so far into a story-template such as 'Save The Cat' or 'Three Act Structure' which can help provide a skeleton look at the story to help me navigate and see where the story is sitting in terms of plot. 

Once the first draft is completed. I often ask the AI to provide full feedback on the story and also ask questions such as 'What would a reader feel is missing? Are there any plot points that do not feel fully resolved?' to help me prepare for the 'story draft' I mentioned earlier. 

I usually work through the story draft without using AI too much, as this is the stage where I'm trying to tidy it up so less involvement makes this easier. 

For the Grammar Draft, I usually go through the draft with a checker such as Grammarly, and then once its all done I'll use another AI model to provide feedback and catch anything that may have been missed. This is about the end of the AI use for the story, as I'll turn to human proof readers for the final stages.  

However, once release, I have used AI to help create social media content, but this is an area I'm still quite new at using it for.

AI: That's fascinating - you've really integrated AI across almost every stage of your process in very thoughtful ways. I'm particularly struck by how intentional you are about asking for tone feedback rather than story suggestions to preserve your creative vision.

User: Sure. So, a recent project was a short story I was working on for an Southern Gothic story I was working on. In this case I used the AI as I described earlier and gathered several inspiration ideas and music which lead to a playlist of music I used when writing. I then posted each chapter into the model for feedback, and the first thing that I really like was having that instant feedback on something which, as a writer, you often don't get feedback until you've finished the whole thing which can take a long, long time!! As such, this provided me with a great motivation to keep going as well as helping me to refine and see my ideas coming to life within the story structure. It really made the process flow better. I did have to reiterate the 'give me feedback not suggestions' aspect a couple of times, but this is something I can see developing as I use the model more often.

AI: That instant feedback aspect sounds really valuable - I can imagine how isolating the writing process can be without that kind of regular input. It's interesting that you had to reinforce the "feedback not suggestions" boundary a few times.

When you're working with AI in this way, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: I would say I am the driving force for the creative decisions, as I make sure to lead with prompts that try to define exactly what I'm looking for. In this way, I think the collaboration is like having an assistant that is always on hand and can perform tasks pretty much instantly, which is ideal really.  I can see how people would be hesitant of using the AI, in the way I explained about providing suggestions over feedback, but this is the same as if you had another person read a story and make suggestions.

AI: That's a really insightful comparison to having a human assistant or reader. It sounds like you've found a way to maintain clear creative ownership while leveraging the AI's availability and speed.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: I think developing writing habits have changed for sure, as having the assistant on hand to provide feedback has been a motivator in some ways, like wanting to make sure I have something to get feedback on makes you want to write more. Of course, refining the model's balance between just praise and constructive criticism is key as sometimes it might feel good for the model to always say what you've done is great, but deep down you want it to help you make the work better even if it means providing some harsh feedback!

AI: That's such an honest insight about the balance between praise and constructive criticism - it sounds like there's a real skill in calibrating that feedback to be genuinely helpful rather than just encouraging. The motivation aspect is really interesting too.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: The biggest concern as a self-published author is that the market can become filled with works by people who have used AI to write a whole story without much actual input from themselves. There are also concerns about the work being used to train models, and this should be looked at carefully as it is such a fine line between plagiarism and inspiration.

AI: Those are really significant concerns - the market saturation issue especially seems like it could fundamentally change the landscape for writers like yourself who are putting in genuine creative effort. The training data question is complex too.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?
