I might also upload a color palette I'm going to use and ask AI to give me 10 theme ideas.  Once I have decided on my color palette and theme, I will do some brainstorming work on my own.  After this step, I will go to AI and give it my color palette and theme, then ask it to generate a list of things I could include in a scrapbook kit.  From there, I will use AI to generate inital sketches or ideas for the style I might use for some of the items.  This could look something like telling the AI I'm creating a happy mail themed scrapbook kit with a color palette (I'd upload the image).  I would ask it to create an image with several ideas for stickers or elements I could include.  I typically will have a pretty long conversation with AI where I continue to ask it to generate idea images.  After this step, I go back and look at all the ideas it gave me, and I will take note of what I want to include in my kit.  At this point, I go to my Procreate app and start drawing/creating things.  Occasionally if I am having trouble, I'll have AI create an element of something tricky - like maybe I can't get my squirrel to look like a squirrel.  Once it generates something, I will download one I like and use it as a reference for my artwork. I used Photoshop's Firefly to generate a few different ideas of what she might look like, collaged some parts of the images together, and then used the result as a concept for the sculpting.

I've seen a few that seem to be attempting to do the entire 3D modeling process from start to finish with a simple text prompt, but as far as I've seen, none of them would actually be helpful for me, yet. I would love some AI tools that could handle the less creative parts of my work though, like retopology and UV unwrapping!

AI: That's really helpful to hear - so AI has streamlined your reference-gathering phase, but the core 3D work remains very much in your hands. And it sounds like you'd welcome AI assistance with the more technical, less creative tasks.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: Currently, I'm mostly concerned that the companies who usually hire 3D artists, like game studios, are under the assumption that AI can do what I do, and have been laying off hundreds of thousands of people in favor of investing in AI tools. I'm not at all worried about AI actually replacing me, just that companies seem to think it can. 

I'm also a little concerned (though more annoyed than concerned) that so many 3D-related AI tools are trying to do the sculpting/modeling and texturing, but the resulting models are such a mess that a human would have to do a ton of clean-up to make them useable. Those tools are seemingly trying to do the fun, creative parts of the work, leaving humans to do the tedious, technical work that we already hate. I want to see more 3D tools aimed at *assisting* a 3D artist, not trying to do our work for us.

I think there are a lot of specific areas where AI would be incredibly helpful in making the 3D pipeline more efficient without making it feel any less creative, and I think we'll start to see more and more specialized tools to handle small parts of the process rather than a single AI trying to do all of it in one go. 

I personally use at least 3 different software programs on every 3D project, sometimes as many as 7 or 8. It doesn't make much sense to me to have a single generative AI doing all of that from a single prompt, but it absolutely makes sense to use AI to handle parts of it.

AI: That's a really thoughtful perspective - moving from these all-in-one AI solutions toward more specialized tools that integrate into your existing multi-software workflow. It sounds like you see a future where AI becomes more of a sophisticated assistant at specific stages rather than trying to replace the entire creative process.

I particularly appreciated your perspective on how AI functions more like an improved search tool for reference gathering, and your distinction between AI assistance versus replacement - especially the idea that the best AI tools should handle the tedious technical work while leaving the creative decisions to humans.

Before we wrap up, is there anything else about your experience with AI in your creative work that you think would be valuable for us to know? Something we haven't covered yet?

User: I am a firm believer that AI can and will be a useful tool in many industries, and artists who are currently concerned about being replaced might be over-reacting for the most part. It reminds me of when Photoshop was first being adopted as an industry standard for art creation, and people who didn't understand how it works were under the impression that the computer is doing all of the work, like you just push a button and it paints a picture. That being said, in some ways, generative AI really is "push a button and it paints a picture." When it comes to art and creativity, I believe anything an AI produces should be treated as a reference or a part of the process, not the final product.

AI: That's a really valuable perspective - the parallel to Photoshop's early adoption is fascinating, and your point about treating AI output as reference material rather than final product gets to the heart of how creative professionals can thoughtfully integrate these tools.

Your insights about the current disconnect between AI capabilities and industry perceptions, along with your vision for more targeted AI assistance tools, will be incredibly helpful for our research on human-AI interaction in creative contexts. I really appreciate how candid you've been about both the opportunities and the challenges you're seeing in your field.

My primary use of AI tools outside of a work context is using them to support me as I run multiple table-top role-playing games. While I am not paid to do so, I do put a professional amount of effort into the games that I run, and each one requires a lot of creative effort and logistics in organizing and running them. AI, in my case Chat GPT, helps tremendously if used correctly with that sort of thing. Much of the time, I use it as a sort of rubber-ducky troubleshooting Plus, where I can bounce ideas off it. It usually doesn't have ideas that are quite up to snuff, but it serves as an alright foundation for expanding on the ideas. Additionally, it works well for organizing and information retrieval on the fly, because I can simply trust that it remembers things we have talked about, and later, I can ask it to remind me about details. Finally, I use programs and websites, such as Homebrewery, that allow you to create pages that mimic the style of official table top gaming books using a custom markdown system. I can copy-paste the entire body of instructions for that system and simply ask Chat GPT questions about it as we go. I am not great at learning via tutorial video or long-winded instructions and I prefer to just jump into a system and learn it on the go, preferably from someone who already knows it. In this way, chat GPT can become a sort of instant subject matter expert about anything I need it to be, and I can ask questions and get help only when I actually need it. 

AI being what it is, however, it has to be double-checked regularly of course.

AI: That's really fascinating - it sounds like you're using AI as this multifaceted creative partner for your tabletop games. I'm particularly intrigued by your description of it as "rubber-ducky troubleshooting Plus."

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: Sure. Traditionally, creative tasks actually have a lot of 'mental grunt work' so to speak. For instance, lets say I have an idea for a small village outside a town. My players are going to this village for whatever plot reason. I am a world-builder at heart, so when I create a location in a campaign, I want it to feel lived-in, real. This applies for anything creative I do, including creative writing as well. Now, before AI tools, I would need to come up with names and occupations, key locations in the village, things like that. I would have to actually think of all this stuff, which is fun and all, but it does cut in to time spent prepping things that matter a lot more for the campaign. With AI, I can just, completely on the fly, come up with a list of people in the village. Background characters who probably won't matter, but you never know what weird things your players might decide to fixate on. Basically, AI works as an improvisational crutch, so I don't have to be quite so quick with my thinking, but I also don't have to spend a lot of prep time coming up with specific ideas. Again, current AI has its flaws here, especially with names. It requires a lot of specific prompting, otherwise it tends to cycle through the same annoying generic names over and over again. But all-in-all, it is a time saver when used correctly.

AI: That's a really insightful distinction you're making between the "mental grunt work" and the more meaningful creative decisions. It sounds like AI helps you delegate the foundational details so you can focus your creative energy elsewhere.

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: Yes, I have a perfect example that kind of ties together both the rubber-ducky troubleshooting aspect, and the mental grunt work thing. Recently, my players were going through a planned encounter (Im running a Ghosts of Saltmarsh campaign, and they were going through the 'haunted house' in the Sinister Secrets of Saltmarsh module) when I was struck with an idea to homebrew an additional dungeon. Without going into too much detail, this manor used to be owned by an alchemist, and I ended up coming up with this idea in my head of this alchemist being sort of like the fantasy version of a DARPA think tank, creating magical and alchemical weapons for the kingdom. Anyway, as this idea was something I came up with on short notice, I used AI to help me come up with ideas for the layout of the dungeon and come up with unique trap ideas tailored to the theme and character of the former owner. The AI came up with some clever ideas, but they were very rough and didn't make a lot of sense when you really thought them through. However, with further refinements of the ideas, both by careful AI prompting and good old fashioned thinking about it in the shower, I managed to flesh them out in an interesting way. My players actually ended up breezing through them hilariously quickly, but everybody agreed it was still a fun session.

AI: That's a great example - I love how you turned that spontaneous idea into a full dungeon experience. It sounds like the AI helped you rapidly prototype the foundation, and then you refined it through that iterative process.

When you're working with AI like that - bouncing ideas back and forth, refining the traps - how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: At this stage of AI development, I would hesitate to call it a collaboration at all if I am being honest and forsaking false modesty. For the most part, it is no more a collaboration than doing math on a calculator is. For instance, I talk with my sister about Dungeons and Dragons, and she doesn't know anything about the gameplay, but sometimes in the discussion she will have a neat idea or I'll get some kind of insight just through the process of airing my ideas out, in the same manner that I would with rubber-ducky troubleshooting. But Im not really collaborating with my sister or the rubber ducky. It is the same with AI. While an LLM occasionally present a unique idea, even when it does so its usually extremely rough and requires a lot of fine-tuning to make it work. While current models of AI are very decent at generating freeform creative stories, they definitely struggle with creating workable ideas under specific mechanical game constraints. And that's just with Dungeons and Dragons, which is by far the most well-known game system. With more niche systems, like Delta Green or Ars Magica, it struggles even more.

AI: That's a really thoughtful perspective - the calculator analogy is particularly striking. It sounds like you see the AI more as a sophisticated tool that helps you think through your own ideas rather than a true creative partner.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: I would say AI has allowed me to be lazier. This is not necessarily a pro or con about AI itself, but rather how you use it. I could likely use AI more aggressively in my creative work and make something that would be passable enough for my players with even less work on my part. But, personally, I would not be happy with the reduction in quality of my work. I think this is a fairly universal experience across any creative endeavor that has been exposed to AI. As you put it, AI is a sophisticated tool, and like any tool, the quality work is going to come from people who actually know how to use it. That being said, while the good craftsman knows how to use a hammer that doesn't have a handle, it would be dramatically better for us, the people who create hammers, to build handles onto them. Or, to not force a metaphor, it should be a priority for us to smooth out the rough edges of AI as a tool. We, the people who work regularly with AI, have a lot of experience with it and a lot of insight into its (many) flaws and weaknesses, and so we are very capable of working around those to still get a quality piece of content. The average person who doesn't have so much exposure, however, will not be able to use the tool to its full extent, or worse, might use it in a way that generates actively poor or maybe even harmful content.

AI: That's a really nuanced take on the "laziness" aspect - recognizing that it's a choice in how you apply the tool rather than an inherent quality of AI itself. Your point about the responsibility to improve the tool for broader use is particularly insightful.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: Well I feel like I've touched on that a little in my previous responses, but to put it more bluntly, AI is going to make people lazy if we aren't exceedingly careful with how we integrate it. I've said it many times before, but the true danger of AI does not come from some sort of Terminator death robot, but rather from a WALL-E-esque overbearing pampering turning us all into mindless blubbery morons. Earlier in the conversation, I compared you and other LLMs to calculators, and I think the comparison is apt. But where a calculator allows humans to export out mathematical reasoning to an outside party, an LLM more insidiously lets us export our linguistic reasoning. Potentially, people don't have to think about how or what to say anymore, they can just generate a response with a machine. Math is important, but speech, knowing how to speak and what to speak, is integral to being a functioning adult.

If I am being honest, my concerns are a little broader than just my hobby field, or any professional field. I think, if misused, if integrated poorly, LLMs will lower the quality of society as a whole, not just specific industries or hobbies. 

But reigning in the doomerism a bit, in a less worst-case-scenario kind of thing? I think a lot of people will just get lazier in the hobby. For a real world example, one of my players used AI to name their character, and after months of play, I still can't remember her name because it's so generic and boring.

AI: That's a powerful distinction you're making - the difference between exporting mathematical reasoning versus linguistic reasoning, and the broader implications of that. The character naming example really brings that home in a concrete way.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: It's hard to predict things. The pace of development for all sorts of technologies has been astounding, so it's difficult to imagine where we might go next. I am hopeful, optimistic even, that AI *will* actually be closer to a collaborative partner like we touched on above. For me, personally, I am constantly coming up with new ways to use AI to organize and format information for my campaigns. Getting a tad sci-fi here, but I think AI could also be used to create some amazing ambiance on the future, by generating background noise on the fly, through use of something similar to Alexa or Google Home. For instance, as my players go into a market, or a deep forest, I could have it trigger a generated busy marketplace noise, or the sound of birds and insects and leaves in the wind, things of that nature could be very intriguing future uses of AI. It's possible much further on it could even be a player at the table!

AI: Those are some really exciting possibilities! I can picture how that ambient sound generation could really enhance the immersive experience for your players. The idea of AI as a future player is particularly intriguing.

Even a simple weekly task of writing up all my Instagram captions for the week, I will know what I want them to push towards or "sell" and so my collaboration with the AI is asking it to provide me a wealth of ideas of topics that I can then pare down and dive deeper every step with. Once I narrow down to one topic for a caption, for example, then the new objective is to write that caption, and first I need a hook...so I go to the AI and ask for a wealth of ideas of hooks that would capture the reader. This process just continues until I feel like I like where we've landed. I frequently find myself saying things like "no I don't like any of these ideas. Let's try something that (is more educational, or more emotionally driven for example)..." and then steer the direction a bit to get ideas closer to what my original vision was. I find it is one of the most valuable things to help me ideate, test, and come to decisions quickly, but keeping myself in creative control is essential with my work.

AI: That's such a clear dynamic - you as the CEO setting direction and the AI as this expansive research partner helping you explore possibilities within your vision. It really sounds like you've found a way to maintain your creative authority while leveraging AI's ability to generate options.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI?

User: Definitely the amount of time I spend on these tasks has been reduced. Sometimes I feel that it is reduced, but then the AI provides me with such great and clear ideas that I am able to execute them significantly better. The quality of my ideas has gone up, my decisions are more decisive because often I've been walked through many potential "outcomes" or ideas and so my confidence is higher, and I know for sure the output is improved. The use of the AI tools in my post process with culling and editing my images has cut my turnaround time on galleries from 12 weeks to about 3! And when I provide better marketing materials, a better client experience, faster service, etc. then I am able to charge more, so I know I've been making significantly more money. I do feel that one downside is the sheer amount of ideas I run through - it can give me a sense of shiny-object syndrome and if not kept in check it can run me a bit crazy and feeling like there's always something new to chase. I've had to become much more intentional about what I take on and how it will promote my long-term objectives.

AI: That's such an honest reflection - the dramatic improvements in turnaround time and quality, but also that challenge of managing the overwhelming flow of possibilities. It sounds like AI has almost amplified your creative potential but required you to develop new discipline around focus.

What concerns, if any, do you have about AI's presence in your field?

User: I worry that relying on it too much in regards to creative steps will remove me from the drivers seat. I avoided using AI for my photo editing for a very long time thinking that was too big of a "part" of what I do to outsource it, that the creative reflection of "me" would no longer be in my work. I personally found a workflow that leans on AI to do the bulk of the work early on, so that I am less crunched for time and have more freedom to revisit the gallery with my own eyes, intentionally making edits and tweaks that I may have missed before or not had time for. So in a sense, I am more removed from the "busy work" of editing like exposing or fixing skin tones, and I am more free to let the creative pieces be tended to intentionally - like crop or adding in depth of shadows, or removing distractions. I think there's hardly any downside on my end for using it in an administrative sense, to draft or template email responses, or to think of the workflows that are more thorough to fit the experience I want a client to have, but on the creative side I have to carefully watch how far removed I become from the heart of my work and to consider what impact that is having on my work.

AI: That's such a thoughtful distinction you've made - using AI to handle the technical busy work so you can focus more intentionally on the truly creative decisions. It sounds like you've found a way to let AI enhance rather than replace your creative voice.

Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

User: I see the photography industry embracing AI more as a "whole." I know in my circles I am one of the few that really embrace these tools and even just the use of AI bots in every day to alleviate the brain fog of general business ownership. I'm excited to see what special AI powered tools may be created. The ones I use now have objectively been the best thing to improve my output, time spent, earning power, etc. But I do worry that with mass acceptance there will be the risk that AI is used more - but not more intentionally. I do not want to fall into that trap. I also see there being a limit to the growth or adoption I can have of these tools because of my standard or guardrails protecting my creative ownership. As I scale my business I think it will help more with administrative stuff. I never ever see myself abandoning the tools I use now, so it can only go "up" from here, but I do wonder how much more. I do find new ways every day to use it, so I'm sure I will continue to explore and invest in these options. I think it will be embraced as photographers dabble in it and realize that if done right you really can still protect and keep your creative ownership and direction.

AI: Those are all the questions I had prepared. You've shared some really thoughtful insights about your experiences with AI in your creative processes. I really appreciate how candidly you shared both the tremendous benefits you've experienced - like cutting your turnaround time from 12 weeks to 3 - as well as the challenges of managing that "shiny object syndrome" and staying focused on your long-term vision. User: I'm a writer and editor, so my flow varies a lot from project to project, but generally it goes like this:
-I go over the initial version of the project, be it notes I took on a show or movie or a rough draft someone else sends me, like a blog post or a manuscript. I take it in and make any obvious edits, like fixing typos or grammar mistakes, or rephrasing things that don't quite sound right.
-I typically like to wait a while before proceeding with the next step, which is thinking over the whole project and how the major ideas fit together. This often involves me rearranging whole paragraphs, cutting and moving chunks of text, more intricate rephrasing, and sometimes adding headers to break up lengthy web posts. If I'm drafting an original post, it usually looks like me organizing thoughts into distinct categories and then weaving them together so they sound like they flow together naturally. If there are a lot of notes and the thoughts are hard to keep track of, I may color-code them to make it easier. If I'm doing something like editing a manuscript, this is where I might make more overarching story or character notes in the margins as I read.
-The final step is to read the whole thing through again and polish it up, making sure that all my edits flow naturally and make sense, and, if it's not my work, that it still sounds like the original author. If I'm editing a manuscript, this is where I'll type out a letter highlighting what I think are the most crucial areas that need looking at. 
-If I'm editing or writing something for the web, the last step is to go through and do basic SEO edits.

AI: That's a really thorough breakdown of your process - I can see how much thought goes into each stage. The way you describe waiting between that initial review and the deeper structural work is particularly interesting.

Walk me through how AI fits into your creative process. Where and when do you find yourself reaching for AI tools?

User: Rarely, if ever, do I use AI in the creative process itself - I enjoy writing and I generating the basics takes the fun out of it for me. What I do use it for is to keep track of character and setting notes in original fiction and when reading complex manuscripts: My notes are often messy and disorganized, and when I was younger I often found myself wishing I could have some sort of Clippy-esque assistant that would just be able to read through my notes and answer any question I had directly. This is especially useful in works with a lot of characters or places to keep track of - doubly so for fictional ones with no other reference material for those things.

AI: That's fascinating - you've essentially found your "Clippy-esque assistant" for organization! I love how specific that use case is. It sounds like you're using AI as a kind of smart filing system for complex information rather than for the creative generation itself.

Can you describe a specific recent project where you used AI this way? What role did it play, and how did that feel for you?

User: I was writing a scene in a fantasy setting that contained dozens of potential character interactions - I'm co-writing a novel with another author in a sort of literary roleplay-type format, so there are a number of potential interactions that could happen at any given time. I was able to use an AI assistant to go through the names and place them in different areas of a large palace ballroom and social scene, and then to move them around naturally as the scene continued. There is no way I could have pulled off the true randomness of the interactions and character groupings without such a tool, and the resulting scenes would not have been nearly as interesting as what we produced.

AI: That's really compelling - using AI to manage the logistics of complex social dynamics so you could focus on the actual storytelling. It sounds like it enabled a level of scene complexity that would have been overwhelming to track manually.

When you're working with AI in that way, how would you describe the collaboration? Who or what is driving the creative decisions?

User: I would say that it's maybe a 60-30-10 split - I wrote most of the background material, but my creative partner is in full control of the lead character, and therefore of wherever the scene goes. The AI's creative input is in choosing who is in what room at which time (aside from a few key characters who need to be in certain places at certain times for story reasons.) 

It does also have a sort of tangential, accidental input, in that sometimes unless I refresh it by pasting the character list in again, the AI will begin to hallucinate characters who don't exist. Some of these characters and names, however, have been interesting enough that I did build them out and add them to the roster for later. None have been used yet, but there's at least one that I'm planning to use in the future.

AI: That's such an interesting dynamic - the AI essentially acting as a logistics coordinator, but then its "mistakes" becoming creative sparks. I love that you've embraced those hallucinated characters as potential story elements rather than just seeing them as errors.

What aspects of your creative work have changed the most since you started using AI this way?

User: I find it much easier to get over my procrastination instincts and start the scene, actually - I have ADHD and I'm awful at logistics, on my worst days it makes my head actually hurt a little bit. Having an easy workaround for that is really helpful, especially on days when I can't take my medication.

It also, as I mentioned before, has made for much more interesting character pairings than I would have thought to make on my own - I like that it forces me to consider less-than-obvious dynamics, like how the King might converse with his son's friends in a casual, convival setting.

But I would have been losing really valuable time exercising that mental muscle when I was young and still had the neuroplasticity for it to Really Take, and I have no doubt that I wouldn't be nearly as good a writer as I am today. And I probably would have wanted to roll my eyes at anyone trying to give me this warning, too. 

I'm also concerned at the sheer amount of what I'm going to call "AI Slop" (quickly, shoddily-made fiction generated entirely by an AI that was given no instructions about theme, message, or any other relevant content other than plot details, and therefore delivers very little human value relative to the time and effort it takes to read it) that seems to be widely available to read now. I know this makes me sound like a snob, but I truly feel like I never used to have to shuffle through so much empty-feeling fiction before I got to something good before. I see a lot of listings for it as an editor, and it's disheartening, because I really can tell the difference, and it loses something I can't put my finger on. It's like the uncanny valley for writing.

AI: Those are really thoughtful concerns. The neuroplasticity point about developing those mental muscles early is particularly striking - that there might be critical periods for learning to think through complex problems that could be bypassed too easily.

It was like it just hit my ear wrong or something. (It's why I became an editor.) It's the same thing with AI - I don't know if it's word choice or cadence or what, but I often just get that feeling, like something's just Off. A little too formulaic, maybe? Or too polished? Reads too much like textbook examples and the Better Answer Formula from like sixth grade? It varies, so it's hard to put a finger on exactly what it is, but those are my best guesses.

AI: That's such a valuable insight - that intuitive ear you have for language picking up on something subtly "off" about the rhythm or authenticity, even when the technical execution might be correct. Looking ahead, how do you see AI's role in your creative work evolving over the next few years?

They couldn't complete the job of pasting railings onto a house without altering the original picture significantly, but I did use them to give me examples of railings on coastal houses with similar themes. I took those AI inspiration railings and found realistic images that I was able to photoshop onto my original pictures for client mock-ups.

For example, when I use the prompt "change the exterior railings from aluminum to wrought iron, use a design popular on high-end coastal vacation homes, do not change any other aspect of the image, the rest of the house should stay exactly the same" I will receive back a new AI generated home, possibly with the correct railings but usually with distorted proportions. If I was starting with a blank canvas, the generative AI models would be very helpful. The issue is that the current generation will change the structure of the house significantly so that it's not the same as original photo. When I get stumped I'll tap AI and provide an image and ask for ideas of themes to try in different scenarios. From that brainstorming I'm usually able to go to the web and find realistic images I can use to photoshop into my original images.

Then instead of browsing through tens of web pages looking through hundreds of pictures for any railing designs that are coastal-adjacent, I can quickly scan pages to find what I need for resource images. The generation from the models doesn't always come out realistic, often is slightly animated, but I've also had luck using Google lens to direct me to real images that are similar to the AI provided ideas.

In the future, once the models are able to separate and manipulate individual aspects of an image I'd like to be able to provide thorough prompts of what I want changed in an image and receive exactly what I asked for. Photoshop is nice but it takes time and I'd like to see AI evolve in the image space to expand how I'm able to precisely edit images.

Since they can't think like humans, often the feedback is not something I would ever need to add to an article. Every creative piece I have read, and even some more informational articles on sites like Medium, which has been written using AI has a very distinctive lack of depth. User: I think AI-assisted writing is ok. I think we have to get with the times and be realistic about its place in our world. It's a good thing for some. I also have to think about content management, work flows and editorial calendars. January through August is usually pretty busy. I also do emergency weather response messaging for ice storms and hurricanes. September through December is usually planning activities.

So I'm usually given the overall theme some phrase, last year it was safety is a habit. This year it was safety in action. And I want to find novel ways to present the information so I ask AI how can we present this content in an interesting and engaging way? I also rely on AI when I'm staring at a blank page and I just need to get some ideas processing. Or if I'm given a bunch of topics that don't really relate to each other, I ask AI how they could be presented. For me it's more of a thinking tool than a writing tool. How do these pieces fit together? What is the best way to present the information that these people have seen a bazillion times?

I'm not sure where it came from. So we had to incorporate his purpose, practice, and people into this fun movie theme. And that kind of sucked. So again the AI was more of a thinker. Let's say the main topic for the week is hydration. The main idea was let hydration be your costar. We would have a safety brief with movie puns and  and how to hydrate and stay hydrated and then at the bottom of each brief, we would have purpose practice and people sections. Why do we hydrate? AI: That sounds like a really challenging creative puzzle - trying to bridge that gap between a fun movie theme and corporate messaging requirements. It's interesting that you describe going back to AI "many times" to work through that connection.
